sections.title: Common Medical Abbreviations
sections.content:
Medical professionals use many abbreviations in charts and communication.

### General Abbreviations
- **Hx**: History
- **Dx**: Diagnosis
- **Px**: Prognosis
- **Rx**: Prescription / Treatment
- **Sx**: Symptoms
- **Tx**: Treatment / Transplant
- **CC**: Chief Complaint
- **v.s.**: Vital Signs

### Medication & Timing
- **b.i.d.**: Twice a day (bis in die)
- **t.i.d.**: Three times a day (ter in die)
- **q.i.d.**: Four times a day (quater in die)
- **p.r.n.**: As needed (pro re nata)
- **p.o.**: By mouth (per os)
- **stat**: Immediately (statim)

sections.title: Month 1 Vocabulary Recap
sections.content:
A summary of the core concepts covered this month:
- **Week 1**: Medical Specialties (Oncology, Cardiology, etc.) and Clinical Routines (Diagnose, Prescribe).
- **Week 2**: Hospital Units (ICU, ER, OR) and Advanced Equipment (Ventilator, Defibrillator, MRI).
- **Week 3**: Patient Intake (Medical/Social/Family History) and Symptom Analysis (Onset, Severity, Progression).

sections.title: Month 1 Grammar Review
sections.content:
Reviewing the three core tenses for clinical communication:

1. **Present Simple**: For permanent facts and professional routines. 
   - *"The nurse **checks** the vitals every morning."*

2. **Present Continuous**: For ongoing actions or temporary situations. 
   - *"The patient **is resting** in the recovery room right now."*

3. **Past Simple**: For medical history and past clinical events. 
   - *"The patient **developed** a fever after the procedure yesterday."*
